body.p: A management consultant was interested in whether workers who telecommute are as productive as those who work in the office. She randomly selected 60 workers who were in each of the following three groups: (1) full-time office workers, (2) part-time telecommuters, (3) full time telecommuters. After analyzing the data, the consultant noticed that the variation within groups was large relative to the the variation between sample means.
Which of the following is the most correct interpretation of this data?

input.choice: The F statistic will be relatively large, so it is likely that the researcher can conclude that the population means may be equal.
The F statistic will be relatively large, so it is likely that the researcher can conclude that the population means are not all equal.
The F statistic will be relatively small, so it is likely that the researcher can conclude that the population means may be equal.
The F statistic will be relatively small, so it is likely that the researcher can conclude that the population means are not all equal.

response.feedback: Incorrect. While it is correct that the researcher is likely not to reject the null hypothesis if the variation within groups (the denominator in the F statistic) is large relative to the variation among means (the numerator in the F statistic), it is not true that the F statistic will be large in this case.

Incorrect. While it is correct that when the F statistic is relatively large that the researcher can likely conclude that the population means are not all equal, the F statistic is not expected to be large in this case. The F statistic is not expected to be large when the within groups variation (the denominator in the F statistic) is large relative to the variation among means (the numerator in the F statistic).

Correct. If the variation within groups (the denominator in the F statistic) is large relative to the variation among means (the numerator in the F statistic), then the F statistic will be relatively small. If the F statistic is relatively small, then the null hypothesis is likely not to be rejected and the researcher should conclude that the population means may be equal.

Incorrect. While it is correct that the F statistic will be relatively small, it is not correct that the researcher should conclude that the means are not all equal. When the F statistic is relatively small, the researcher should not reject the null hypothesis.

body.p: A psychology program coordinator was interested in whether there was a difference in salary for the mental health counseling graduates of her masterâ€™s degree program based on whether they obtained employment in (1) a sole proprietor private practice, (2) a group private practice, (3) hospitals or (4) government agencies. After analyzing the data for 90 recent graduates, the consultant noticed that the variation within groups was small relative to the the variation between sample means.
Which of the following is the most correct interpretation of this data?

input.choice: The F statistic will be relatively large, so it is likely that the researcher can conclude that the population means may be equal.
The F statistic will be relatively large, so it is likely that the researcher can conclude that the population means are not all equal.
The F statistic will be relatively small, so it is likely that the researcher can conclude that the population means may be equal.
The F statistic will be relatively small, so it is likely that the researcher can conclude that the population means are not all equal.

response.feedback: Incorrect. While it is correct that the F statistic will be large in this case, it is not true that researchers should conclude that the population means may be equal. When the F statistic is large, the researcher is likely to reject the null hypothesis.

Correct. When the variation within groups (the denominator in the F statistic) is relatively large small compared to the variation among sample means (the numerator in the F statistic), the F statistic will be large. When the F statistic is large, the researcher is likely to reject the null hypothesis and conclude that the population means are not all equal.

Incorrect. While it is true that when the F statistic is relatively small, then the researcher should conclude that the population means may be equal (i.e, do not reject H0), but in this case the F statistic should will not be small. In this case the F statistic will be large because the variation within groups (the denominator in the F statistic) is relatively small compared to the variation among sample means (the numerator in the F statistic).

Incorrect. It is not correct that the researcher should conclude that the means are not all equal when the F statistic is small. Additionally, in this case the F statistic will be large because the variation within groups (the denominator in the F statistic) is relatively small compared to the variation among sample means (the numerator in the F statistic).
